subject: Re: [junit] Junit support for non-standard distributed applications
msgSnippet: ... Conventional wisdom says to use mock objects to simulate the network.  The client tests use mock objects to simulate the server; the server tests use mock
messageBody:
guillaume_berche wrote:

> Hello,
>
> I'm working on a Java layer implementing various communication
> infrastructrure betwen processes based on raw TCP and UDP. I would
> like to test it using Junit. However, this requires me to write a
> test case which is distributed among many processes which act as
> client/servers.
>

Conventional wisdom says to use mock objects to simulate the network. The
client tests use mock objects to simulate the server; the server tests use
mock objects to simulate the client. The client and server stay decoupled
and can be developed concurrently by the team. These tests get run very
frequently and they don't take long to run.

On a less frequent basis, and possibly taking more time to run, other tests
using the "real" objects are run for end-to-end testing. Ideally, the only
difference is that the mock objects are dynamically removed from the tests by
plugging in a new factory.
